Package net.proteusframework.core.locale Description

Localization related classes.

All localization / internationalization stems from TextSources. Before we get into the details, lets start with a bit of history first that may help in understanding the API. The initial internationalization method was done via LocalizedObjects (e.g. LocalizedText, LocalizedImages, ...). This covered the case of application specified localization. Then the need arose to have a standardized key that could be stored in a database, so end-user supplied localizations could be defined. That is how LocalizedObjectKey was born and integrated into LocaleSource. For a while we had APIs that worked with LocalizedObjectKey and some that worked with LocalizedText and some that worked with both. Eventually, TextSource was created and most APIs were updated to use TextSource instead of LocalizedObjectKey and LocalizedText directly. Then LocalizedObjectKey and LocalizedText were made to implement TextSource. And that is how the current state of the internationalization API in Proteus came to be.

APIs should typically consume TextSource and interfaces that produce internationalized text should produce TextSource. The most common implementation of TextSource is LocalizedObjectKey. Other common TextSource implementations are created via the TextSources class. The most common producer of TextSource is NamedObject.

Proteus provides LocaleSource and several implementations for accessing and storing localization information. Hibernate integration is provided via a BasicType implementation that is registered with Hibernate, so no further configuration is required for people using a LocalizedObjectKey as an Entity property.

For applications that capture localized text, the class LocalizationInputProvider provides a mechanism to retrieve and store information related to translations and localization input. Other modules in Proteus provide further integration with LocalizationInputProvider including a user interface.
